byline.contributor: Monica Davey reported from Jefferson City, and Shaila Dewan from New York.
byline.original: By MONICA DAVEY and SHAILA DEWAN

abstract: White suburban Republicans, Tea Party group and conservative leaders are among coalition backing measure from Missouri State Senate calling for limits in amount of revenue towns can retain from traffic fines; bill, which passed unanimously, is among host of post-Ferguson measures seeking to reduce law enforcement practices that many say disproportionately impact poor and minorities.
lead_paragraph: After Ferguson, white Republicans and leaders from conservative groups joined black lawmakers in backing a bill to limit the revenue Missouri towns can keep from traffic fines.

headline.main: Law Enforcement Concerns Create Unlikely Alliances in Missouri and Beyond
headline.print_headline: Law Enforcement Concerns Create Unlikely Alliances in Missouri and Beyond

snippet: After Ferguson, white Republicans and leaders from conservative groups joined black lawmakers in backing a bill to limit the revenue Missouri towns can keep from traffic fines.
